Distance between Gaussian Mixture Models

Source: R/gmm_gmmdist.R
gmmdist.Rd

Compute the distance between two mixtures of Gaussians. For consistency with our package, we only accept the fitted mixtures from one of the functions delivered in the package.

gmmdist(
  gmmobj1,
  gmmobj2,
  dtype = c("L2", "MCOT", "CS"),
  base.metric = c("L2", "Wass2", "CS")
)

Arguments

gmmobj1

first gmm-like object from one of our functions.
gmmobj2

second gmm-like object from one of our functions.
dtype

(case-insensitive) type of the distance between mixtures, including

"L2"

\(L_2\) distance.

"MCOT"

mixture component optimal transport by Liu and Huang (2000).

"CS"

Cauchy-Schwarz divergence by Kampa et al. (2011).

"AW"

approximate wasserstein distance for mixture model by Chen et al. (2019).
base.metric

(case-insensitive) name of a base metric for optimal transport-based methods, including

"L2"

\(L_2\) metric.

"Wass2"

2-Wasserstein metric.

Value

computed distance value.

References

You K (2019). “\$L\_2\$ Distance between Gaussian Mixture Models.”

Liu Z, Huang Q (2000). “A New Distance Measure for Probability Distribution Function of Mixture Type.” In 2000 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing. Proceedings (Cat. No.00CH37100), volume 1, 616--619. doi: 10.1109/ICASSP.2000.862057 .

Kampa K, Hasanbelliu E, Principe JC (2011-jul). “Closed-Form Cauchy-Schwarz PDF Divergence for Mixture of Gaussians.” In The 2011 International Joint Conference on Neural Networks, 2578--2585. doi: 10.1109/IJCNN.2011.6033555 .

Chen Y, Georgiou TT, Tannenbaum A (2019). “Optimal Transport for Gaussian Mixture Models.” IEEE Access, 7, 6269--6278. doi: 10.1109/ACCESS.2018.2889838 .

Examples

# \donttest{
# -------------------------------------------------------------
#                   Distance for Gaussian Mixtures
#
# Data 1 : use SMILEY data 'gensmiley()' function.
# Data 2 : SMILEY data are translated and rotated.
# -------------------------------------------------------------
## GENERATE DATA
#  set up
ndata = 10
ntot  = 2*ndata
gap   = 15
rot   = qr.Q(qr(matrix(rnorm(4),ncol=2)))

#  generate
list_data = list()
for (i in 1:ndata){
  list_data[[i]] = (gensmiley(n=150, sd=0.1)$data)
}
for (j in (ndata+1):ntot){
  list_data[[j]] = (gensmiley(n=150, sd=0.1)$data)%*%rot + gap
}

## FIT GMM MODELS WITH K=4
list_gmm = list()
for (i in 1:ntot){
  list_gmm[[i]] = gmm(list_data[[i]], k=4)
}

## COMPUTE PAIRWISE DISTANCE
distL2 = array(0,c(ntot,ntot))
distCS = array(0,c(ntot,ntot))
distAW = array(0,c(ntot,ntot))
distML = array(0,c(ntot,ntot))
distMW = array(0,c(ntot,ntot))
distMC = array(0,c(ntot,ntot))
for (i in 1:(ntot-1)){
  gi = list_gmm[[i]]
  for (j in (i+1):ntot){
    gj = list_gmm[[j]]
    distCS[i,j] <- distCS[j,i] <- gmmdist(gi, gj, dtype="cs")
    distL2[i,j] <- distL2[j,i] <- gmmdist(gi, gj, dtype="l2")
    distAW[i,j] <- distAW[j,i] <- gmmdist(gi, gj, dtype="aw")
    distML[i,j] <- distML[j,i] <- gmmdist(gi, gj, dtype="MCOT", base.metric="L2")
    distMW[i,j] <- distMW[j,i] <- gmmdist(gi, gj, dtype="MCOT", base.metric="wass2")
    distMC[i,j] <- distMC[j,i] <- gmmdist(gi, gj, dtype="MCOT", base.metric="cs")
  }
}

## VISUALIZE
gcol <- gray((0:64)/64)
opar <- par(no.readonly=TRUE)
par(mfrow=c(2,4), pty="s")
plot(list_data[[1]], main="SMILEY data", pch=19)
image(distL2[,ntot:1], axes=FALSE, col=gcol, main="L2")
image(distCS[,ntot:1], axes=FALSE, col=gcol, main="CS")
image(distAW[,ntot:1], axes=FALSE, col=gcol, main="AW")
image(distML[,ntot:1], axes=FALSE, col=gcol, main="MCOT+L2 metric")
image(distMW[,ntot:1], axes=FALSE, col=gcol, main="MCOT+Wass2 metric")
image(distMC[,ntot:1], axes=FALSE, col=gcol, main="MCOT+CS divergence")
par(opar)

# }
